author: Jason I

review: I have a SmartTV, so adding Apple TV was a bit superfluous. Nevertheless, there are several features that made the purchase worthwhile for me.  To begin with, the whole family has a wide range of Apple devices, from iPod to iPhone to iPad, and the main feature I was interested in was Airplay.  Using Airplay, you can take whatever is on your screen and mirror it to the TV (this only works with the iPhone4S and later items, so the iPhone 4 and the iPod were left out).  You can also send the sound from your iOS device to your TV and from there to the surround sound system using Airplay.  Some games are designed for Airplay use as well.  Sky Gamblers is a good example of this.  You see the main view on the TV, and you have the secondary view, in this case your radar, on your phone.  There is a bit of lag from time to time, but you can get used to it.  Likewise, you can use Airplay to show photos and videos from your iOS device.  Unfortunately, in order to prevent “buffering” issues while playing back, Apple TV buffers much of the video beforehand, which means a long wait from when you press play to when you see video playing.Apple TV offers many other features, but I find that I rarely use them.  It is connected into iTunes, so your iTunes content is available to you, but other than that, I find most of the features are already present on my SmartTV.  For example, while Apple TV has Netflix, and a very nice interface at that, my TV has a Netflix button that has me in Netflix very quickly.  Other things like NHL Game Center are also available, but again, easier on my SmartTV.Apple TV is missing some things that you may expect from a SmartTV add-in box (like Roku).  There is no Pandora, Slacker, etc.  On the other hand, it can play anything from your iPhone, so you can just fire up Slacker from there instead.  Also, the remote is terrible.  Tiny, oversensitive, just not very good.  Fortunately, you can download the Remote app from the App Store (free) and control your Apple TV from your iOS device instead.  Another drawback, all it includes is the power cable.  You will need your own HDMI cable to attach it to your TV and you will need your own TOSLINK cable to connect it to your stereo (unless you use HDMI for that too).  Bad move on Apple’s part, since it won’t just work out of the box.  HDMI cables are cheap, and it would have been a good idea to include one, just to have people not have to go out to get one after they open the box and discover there isn’t one.Bottom line, Apple TV is great if you are already into the Apple Ecosystem.  If you have iPhones, pods, and pads, this is the gadget for you.  If you already have a SmartTV, then you already have most of the features here.  If you don’t have a SmartTV and are looking for an add-in to give you those functions, you may do better with a Roku or the like, but you won’t have the Apple functionality (Airplay and iTunes).
